data.title: Lanier’s number retired: Former Goldeyes manager to be honoured in July
data.meta_description: The Winnipeg Goldeyes are taking another number out of circulation.
data.text:
Article content

The Winnipeg Goldeyes are taking another number out of circulation.

Article content

Technically, No. 22 has been unofficially retired since former manager Hal Lanier left the organization after 10 seasons, but it’s now the fifth number to be retired by the American Association franchise.

We apologize, but this video has failed to load.

Try refreshing your browser, or

tap here to see other videos from our team.

Lanier’s number retired: Former Goldeyes manager to be honoured in July Back to video

The Goldeyes made the announcement on Monday morning and the former major leaguer will be honoured on July 12 prior to a game against the Sioux Falls Canaries.

“Hal Lanier brought class and integrity to the Northern League,” Goldeyes owner and president Sam Katz said in a press release. “The league originally told us we would never be able to land someone with Hal’s resume. Luckily, we didn’t listen to them, because Hal is one of the best things to have ever happened to the Goldeyes, and we are fortunate to have had someone of his stature leading our club.”

Article content

Advertisement 3

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Lanier served as manager for the Goldeyes from 1996 to 2005, compiling an overall record of 523-361 (.592 winning percentage), leading the Goldeyes to eight playoff berths and five trips to the Northern League Championship Series.

“As we celebrate the Goldeyes’ 25th anniversary, it’s important that we remember the people who helped make the Goldeyes what they are today,” Goldeyes general manager Andrew Collier said in a press release. “Hal brought his knowledge and experience as a Major League player and manager to the Goldeyes, and helped cement the team as a mainstay in the Winnipeg sports scene. I am very pleased that we will be honouring someone who was an integral part of our success both on and off the field.”

Advertisement 4

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

The 75-year-old is heading into his fourth season as manager of the Ottawa Champions of the Can-Am League and he helped the organization capture a league title in 2016.

Lanier also managed the Sussex Skyhawks to a Can-Am League championship in 2008.

Lanier spent 10 seasons as an infielder in the big leagues with the San Francisco Giants and New York Yankees before moving into a managing role in the minors with the St Louis Cardinals before spending five seasons as the third base coach for Whitey Herzog with the big club.

Lanier spent three seasons as manager of the Houston Astros, earning National League manager of the year honours in 1986.
